line_1: On which she est did blow, and made the heart right glad.
line_2: Such as the crew did wield whom Bacchus lad,

line_1: On which she est did blow, and made the heart right glad.
line_2: And in her left a bugle-horn she had,

line_1: Whose birth has made a parish glad,
line_2: So have I known an aukward lad,

line_1: And every loyal heart is glad
line_2: In Spring's fresh robes the trees are clad,

line_1: Were never folk so glad,
line_2: As if Cheapside were mad.

line_1: His pomp, his piety was glad;
line_2: In armour, or in ephod clad,

line_1: The Lord is great and glad.
line_2: And good to goodness add:

line_1: Haste, happy days, and make all Nature glad —
line_2: O can ye chear pale Sickness' gloomy bed,

line_1: Alone can life's pilgrimage glad,
line_2: And whose absence Prosperity sad!

line_1: The stranger guests she viewed with welcome glad,
line_2: To fill the glowing bowl her nymphs she bad,

line_1: Surely no lark in spring was e'er so glad
line_2: To see the morn, as I to see my lad;

line_1: And when she saw me very glad,
line_2: Cry'd out, She looks like one that's mad!

line_1: Yet ne'ertheless I am right glad,
line_2: To sit beside you, Dad.

line_1: And sometimes would he make our Valley glad;
line_2: Who felt each Worth, for every Worth he had;

line_1: And sometimes would he make our Valley glad;
line_2: As little touch'd as any Man's with Bad:

line_1: And sometimes would he make our Valley glad;
line_2: Him through their inmost Walks the Muses lad,

line_1: Sweet Airs and Song; and without Hurry all seem'd glad.
line_2: Like a green Isle, it broad beneath them spred,

line_1: Sweet Airs and Song; and without Hurry all seem'd glad.
line_2: And tufted Groves to shade the Meadow-Bed,

line_1: And loved to bid the innocent be glad;
line_2: The lip of tenderness that soothed the sad,

line_1: And to avoid the parching Sun are glad.
line_2: Not pensive now, we bless the friendly Shade;

line_1: O GOD, who bid'st my Heart be glad
line_2: In all I do I feel thy Aid;
